After years of not using Samsung's top-of-the-food-chain devices, I finally gave it a shot with the S9 Plus. Unfortunately, I had to return the device next day.THE GOOD:Samsung still has excellent built quality and clever features that make their devices unique. I especially fell in love with the DeX feature. Being able to turn your phone into a fully functioning desktop computer is just cool and amazing. I first got introduced to this kind of feature on a Huawei Mate 10 Pro (which I also had to return for other reasons). Once I actually got exposed to the DeX, I knew I wanted it in my life.Samsung's displays are just amazing and unrivaled! I doubt I have to say more. :)The camera was ok. For some reason, it didn't live up to the hype; at least not in my opinion. Compared to my Pixel 2 XL pictures, the ones taken with the Samsung were way too bright, sometimes over exposed, looked rather soft and lacked depth / details. In this days and age, that's nitpicking, I know. All top tier phones take great pictures. It doesn't matter which phone you get, every single one of them will take great pictures while letting you down in one or another department.THE "DOESN'T MATTER MUCH BUT STILL ANNOYING":Samsung's launcher (user interface) has improved a lot. I still don't really care for it but I could at least have lived with it. I hate how all the settings have been moved around and how you have to search for them in spots where you would never have expected them. For instance WiFi Calling. Why is that in the settings of the phone app rather than under Network and Connectivity?Pre-installed apps are just as annoying today as they were a few years back. Granted, this days, it isn't as much as it used to be but why not making them uninstallable rather than baking them into the OS? I know I can disable an app, however, I would prefer if it isn't there in the first place!Samsung's need to duplicate virtually all and any of Google's services is, in my opinion, a waste of resources and it doesn't make their platform more attractive. Why do I need a Samsung Clock app that doesn't do any more than the default Android Clock app? Why do I need a Samsung Phone app where the default Android Phone app is just fine? Same goes for Samsung Mail, Samsung Calendar and a bunch more. If I could at least remove them and replace them with the stock Android apps, I would be more inclined to buy a Samsung phone.Bixby is a whole other story! From the get-go, I had no intention of using Samsung's assistant. Yet, here she was, right in my face. I could deactivate her on the home screen, however, there was no way of deactivating the assistant entirely. I remembered that the Bixby button (which I hit multiple times already by accident) could be deactivated. Yeah, sure! You first have to create a Samsung account, then configure Bixby just to be able to finally click on a settings icon in Bixby and deactivate the hardware button. I don't know who thought of this nonsense!As mentioned, I would have been able to live with the above. Annoying (to me), yes, but I could live with it.THE BAD:The most important thing on the phone simply doesn't work right: network reception! I got 1 to 0 bars of mobile reception where every other phone in the house got at least 3. I constantly lost network. Researching this problem online, I learnt that this has been an issue with all of Samsung's high end devices since the Oreo update. The forums across the globe are filled with user complaints. The German Samsung forum, for example, has 59 pages of users complaining about network reception issues on the S8, S8+, Note 8, S9 and S9+. This has been going on since February, it seems. Users state that their phones were fine with Android 7.x but since the Oreo update, everything is a mess.Strangely, this also affects WiFi calling, too. I wasn't able to place a single call without either fading out conversations or mute calls. There are a gazillion sites out there claiming to have the fix for this issues but none of them actually work. Samsung has yet to acknowledge the problem. Instead, they blame your network provider and make you hard reset your device. If that doesn't help, they will offer you to exchange your brand new device with a refurbished one under warranty - at least that's what they offered me! In between, Samsung issued an update to improve network stability but, looking around in the web, that didn't seem to have solved the problem.Regardless, a phone that can't even do the basic task of being a phone is useless to me, so, I returned mine.

I got this phone last month to replace my old iPhone, as I was tired of Apple for a variety of reasons. I was impressed with the picture quality and, reading the reviews, I convinced myself to switch to the Gallaxy S9. When I first received it, I loved it - and this would be a very different review if I wrote it then. But I live in Europe and soon the problems started to show. No Samsung Pay - at all. I checked everywhere and no one has an answer on how to fix that. Then the camera started freezing. It wouldn't go from selfie to portrait nor from camera to gallery without needing a restart. I now just left Samsung's flagship shop in London to find out what to do. Turns out my ONLY choice is to send it back to America and hope for the best. So if you live abroad, know certain features on your phone just will not work and if you ever need assistance, you flat out won't get it.

I tried out a Samsung a few years ago, the S6 actually, and I really couldn't get into their take on Android. TouchWiz, as they called it was a mess, full of unwanted bloatware and a jerky-jerky feel to the software that turned me off. The battery life was horrible on the phone too, which was why I returned mine for an exchange within the two-week grace period. The 7 tempted me and the 8, but something kept telling me to go with iPhone or another Android instead.I jump around with my phones quite a lot--I've used every imaginable playform and several different phones--I am not a 'fanboy' of any OS or brand. There are things I love about iOS and things I love about Android. Those love/hate aspects are the biggest reasons I can't fully commit to either ecosystem and why I am switching phones like a lunatic every year. This past year, I used the Essential Phone which, through constant updates and fixes, finally became a good little phone by the end. However, switching to the S9, I feel like I've gone from roughing it to living in luxury. Take a moment and check out my review below.HardwareThis thing is a beauty. Seriously. It¡¯s refined and though it is basically the same design as the S8, for my money it¡¯s still the best-looking phone on the market. I would like it to be a teensy bit wider, as the screen appears every-so-slightly too narrow, but really that¡¯s nit-picking to the extreme. The feel in your hand is fantastic and looks like it should be expensive.Yes, the headphone jack is still present<U+2014>Samsung would have to eat far too many of their own words to remove that little feature. However, so many other companies are doing away with it, one wonders just how long Samsung will keep this stubbornness up. Personally, I would gladly do away with it in exchange for a bigger battery<U+2014>something this phone sorely needs. Maybe someday. I¡¯m sure Apple has a whole campaign of told-you-so commercials just waiting for that day to come. The S9 does come with a fast charging adapter and a great pair of headphones.The external speakers are fantastic, a big step above what they've had in the past. They harken back to the old HTC One in terms of sound quality, and they might even do that phone one better. The volume is loud with little distortion, except for at the very highest levels.The screen is, well, the best you can buy. Samsung has perfected screens and everyone else is just playing catchup. The colors are bright, and the images are crisp. It does inspire a lot of oohing and ahhhing that¡¯s for sure.Inside, the S9 has all the goods you would expect in a 2018 flagship phone. Sporting a Snapdragon 845 process, this baby is smooth and fast as can be. I've never used a phone with such a quick response to commands. The base model comes with 64gb of storage and the option to add a ridiculous amount of extra storage with an SD card. You can also buy options with 128GB or 256GB, but given it's expandable, I see little reason to go with the larger storage models.The 4GB of memory might disappoint some people, but the vast majority of users will never feel the difference. However, if you disagree, there's always the S9+ or Note 9, both of which have more memory.Overall, this phone has everything you want in a flagship smartphone, in terms of both design and power.SoftwareI can say, though there is still much room for refinement, Samsung has done a great job with its current software. Unlike the S6 and S8 I used before, this baby isn¡¯t bogged down by near as many redundancies and bloatware. Oh, the bloatware is still there, no doubt. But it all works together better than ever before. I¡¯m still sifting through just how much of this stuff I really need, but after the barebones pure Android experience of Essential Phone, I am enjoying the endless possibilities afforded by Samsung¡¯s interconnected experience.And then we come to Bixby. Poor little Bixby. I don¡¯t know why Samsung is sticking with this thing<U+2014>in its current form, even after updates, it¡¯s not good, nor is it anywhere near as useful as the Google assistant. The swipe right screen, which is Bixby¡¯s home, is still a clunky mess. I¡¯d much prefer to have the usual Google home screen there instead. It feels like a lot of wasted space.Bixby takes a while to load up when you call it and frequently misses words or mistakes words. When you ask it a question, it more often than not pulls up a web search list. That¡¯s not good enough when Google¡¯s assistant is available too and far better at retrieving information and reading it to you. Right now this thing is not even as useful as Siri, and that¡¯s saying something.Fortunately, Bixby is easily ignored. Samsung Pay more than makes up for it. The ability to pay through NFC almost anywhere is amazing.Unlike previous incarnations, Samsung¡¯s refinements and additions to Android feel complimentary now. Having used pure stock Android for the previous year, I can say these tweaks are welcome and make the experience feel more united, rather than a collection of separate apps.CameraWow. That¡¯s all I can say. I know, I know, the S9+ has a dual camera setup. I get that, but it¡¯s also more expensive and a lot larger. Don¡¯t knock the camera on the S9<U+2014>it takes amazing photos, especially in low light, and the videos are eye-catching. This baby even takes good portrait-style photos with the blurry background and all. And slow-motion mode is breath-taking. If you want a great camera, the S9 is one of the best out there. Sure, there are miniscule nit-picks to the photo quality compared to the + and to the iPhone X, but no one will go through your photos so closely to even notice.Trust me. You will love this camera.Battery LifeThis is a major disappointment. The battery on the S9 is the same one they used last year, from what I¡¯ve read, and it desperately needed an upgrade. The batter life is horrendous for a flagship phone, and it's the biggest reason I have to give 4 stars instead of 5. A real shame. If you're a power user, you might want to find another phone, because you'll be shocked by just how quickly this phone dies.The ExperienceThis is where it all comes together. Your phone may have super duper specs on the inside and fancy features in the software, or a crazy good dual camera, but the experience you have while using your phone is really what determines your opinion. I have never had an experience like the one I'm having with the Galaxy S9. I feel a connection to it, which I know may sound odd, but it's true.The PIE update, with One UI added, has been a revelation. Truly, it almost feels like I have a brand new phone now. I'm loving the look, feel, and smoothness of the operation. It's a stunning update.The little things Samsung offers, like alternate skins and themes for the interface, allow you to make it your own. They personalize your device and give you a sense of ownership. And above all, this phone just works and works extremely well. It's a joy to use no matter what I'm doing. In terms of the user experience, I've never felt quite this satisfied with any device. If only the battery life didn't rain on my parade!VerdictI¡¯m happy with this phone and the PIE and One UI updates have been incredible. This is a flagship phone, no doubt about it, and you¡¯ll be very pleased if you go with it. The camera is top-of-the-line, the software is smooth and fantastic, and the screen is the best you can buy. Get it! I think you'll love it.

I'm upgrading from a bricked Nexus 5X so the performance and feel of this phone is leaps and bounds beyond what I'm used to.  I've been using Google phones for a number of years so I was concerned about Samsung wrecking the UI.  But after disabling Bixby and its button, it's pretty much back to working like vanilla Android as far as I'm concerned.I like the "infinity screen" for the fact that it increases screen size without greatly increasing the size of the phone.  My 5X is only a bit smaller than the S9+!My biggest complaint, and the reason I'm giving 4/5 stars is for the exterior feel of this phone - it's very very slippery!  The 5X has a rubberized coating that makes it easy to pick up and hold and also not slide off of surfaces, I greatly miss that.  For example when I navigate while driving I put the phone on my right knee.  This new phone immediately slides right off.  I'm definitely going to get some kind of case or grippy skin for it.I am using this phone on a Red Pocket plan with Verizon service.

Like the title says... I was using an iPhone 5c which was incredibly slow thanks to apple purposefully making it damn near impossible to use after the last and final update they sent me about a year ago.  I'll break down what I like and do not like about this phone though:Pros - slim, shiny, beautiful screen, fast response times from everything to opening the phone to the apps I use as well as the internet.  If has built in facial and iris recognition and allows you have the alternative option of putting a code or password into the phone to open it.  (Honestly I highly recommend choosing a backup option to unlock the phone because although the facial and iris recognition is great, it's not flawless especially if you're wearing a costume, heavy makeup, etc.) The sound is great and the quality of the photos is amazing compared to what I had before.Cons: the phone is much heavier than what I am used to or what I had expected.  The camera, although great when you're far away, has absolutely awful quality (much worse than my old iPhone) when you zoom in.  The price for the phone was about average.  I found this to be a better deal than the Google XL 2, or the iPhone X which in my opinion were both overpriced, however I still think 760 with taxes is a little much for a phone, especially one that didn't introduce anything new to the market that wasn't already out there and available with other products and companies.  Lastly, if you are an iOS user and are considering switching to android like I did, heed my warning, because I can't put this in larger letters if I tried: DO NOT FORGET TO DEACTIVATE YOUR IMESSAGES.  if you do not deactivate them, you will NOT be able to receive imessages (texts) from ANY iPhone or iPad user.  I ran into a huge issue with this and even though I was incredibly careful, I STILL had to visit the apple webpage to manually deactivate my apple account in order to fix the issue.All in all, I am very happy with my purchase.P.S.: note that if you are changing from iOS to android, you may also run into a problem transferring apps and logging back into any cross phone / platform games that you were playing.  I had to find work around and contact account recovery due to apple using game center vs. Android using Google and Facebook.  I highly suggest you link any games you can't live without to Facebook or gmail prior to switching devices or you will find yourself switching back and forth between devices several times to resolve the issue.

This is a pretty good smartphone.  The camera still struggles under low light conditions, but that's true of all smartphones.  Beyond that, nice display, water resistant, it's not much different than any of the recent competitors,  or even those one or two generations out of date.  So, no 4 or 5 stars.  If you own an S6 or equivalent  there really isn't five or six hundred dollars worth of difference here.  It's not less money and doesn't do anything all that much better.  It has two drawbacks.  First, is Samsung's proprietary bloatware and manipulation of Android.  For that reason alone, this is my last Samsung phone.  Second, and really objectionable, is the worthless Bixby. It does nothing for the user.  It is extremely limited in its ability to customize. It only gets about 10% of voice commands/requests correct.  Google is far better.  And, Samsung is so smitten by its worthless Bixby feature it installed a button just below the volume rocker to turn it on. It's very easy to press the stupid Bixby button while trying to change the volume.  In short, who needs to upgrade?  For what?  A marginally better snapshot camera?  A reliable (for a change) battery?  For Bixby?  I bought this phone because my S6 was just about done and I had to change phones to use Xfinity anyway. Unless you have to get a new phone, ask yourself,  regardless of brand, do you really have nothing better to do with $500 to $1000+?

iPhone user and totally converted after trying S9+. Bought EU model with Equinios processor, 256 GB internal memory and 400 GB SD card. I need it for shooting video and 656 GB of available memory I have finally no problem.Camera is to die for, love colors and depth, comparable to iPhone X, so iPhone lost its prevous advantage.Display is the best currently available on any smartphone. Samsung definitely leads the game here.Sounds is stereo with Dolby, what makes it way more pleasant than iPhoneX currently.In terms of speed, it is maybe because of software, I do not play games, but for everything else I feel that Galaxy S9+ is faster than iPhone. 6 GB RAM makes lot of sense, as well.It really feels like fast computer and going back to anything slower is painful.Fast charging and wireless fast charging are added bonuses, it takes few short hours and works perfect.At current price for global market models (2 SIM cards, faster processor, 256 GB memory) and I paid 930 $, it is way better proposition than iPhone X. It is much cheaper to pay 100% for the phone and pick some smarter plan than to buy on monthly plan. Do the math.Bottom line, as convert from Apple, I may witness that Galaxy is truly an achievement, design, quality, functionality and reliability. It is all there now.

I purchased a s9+ about a month ago from Samsung , this phone and all the phones that have Bixby have a system Virus that Samsung tells me you can not remove. This is why it is a virus, it installs itself you can turn it off but it will reinstall itself and turn itself back on. When it does that it gives complete access to everything on your phone if you accidently hit the button on the side or swipe left. and it can't be stopped according to Samsung customer service.This virus is bad, "REAL BAD"  unless of course you do not mind sharing all you phone numbers , emails , texts call history email addresses, photos , videos , etc.I love the phone it is the best camera I have seen, but the phone itself stinks, because of this virus.if you accidentally pick up the phone and press the button or swipe too far left  Bang! the virus is back in 6 different places and all your personal data is accessible to the virus even though you spent the time to turn  the VIRUS off in the 6 places and remove permissions ,  one little slip of the finger and the virus is back in full force.I have no Idea why Samsung would insist on accessing my personal information when I have tried to disable their virus software BIXBY , and it still propagates back on the phone.Samsung told me it is not a virus, what is the definition of a virus, my thoughts are , if it is something you can not stop from propagating in the OS , and It has full access to everything on your phone , and once deleted or deactivated propagates itself back on the phone, and again gives full access to you personal files and information to the Virus called "BIXBY"

I am thrilled so far.I have had this phone for only a week, so time will tell what longevity will hold for me.I can honestly say that if the phone I own now, is still 'acting' like the same phone 6-months or a year from now (in regards to not developing glitches/issues), that it will be the best phone I have ever owned.I have never and will never own an Iphone, and I have never been a samsung anything guy in the past either. I have never liked samsung electronics (always found them 'cheaper' than competitor products). My first samsung phone 20 years ago (flip phone) was complete rubbish. My Son's Galaxy 5 (or 6?) was a nightmare. THIS PHONE however, has won me over.- Reception - best.- App speed - best.- Battery - very good.- Glitchiness - none.- Voice quality - very good.- Visuals - outstanding.The ONLY thing NOT superior on this phone vs my last is sound. I have had HTC flagship phones in  the past couple of years and they are way ahead of their time with speaker/voice/sound quality. The bar was set very high with the HTC and I never expected the Galaxy to match it, nevermind beat it, BUT the Galaxy makes a valiant effort. I will miss that sound with my old phone, but if that is the only thing I have to sacrifice for an otherwise far superior phone, I can live with that.Only other concern I have is that the responsiveness to the screen, with or without a screen protector sometimes has me thinking it is not capturing my finger taps and swipes, but it is very minor (for now). I have read reviews where this has become a major issue for some so i will need to keep an eye out for that.I will post back after some time of using this phone to inform if it is still holding up to this gleaming review.I am on T-mobile with this phone as a point of reference.Lastly, I really wanted to buy an unbranded phone here from Amazon, but I had to buy from T-mobile because I have read that you cannot utilize the wifi calling feature with unbranded phones. While this is not a HUGE deal for me, it is a feature that while I don't use often, it would be a nice feature to have if I need it. That said, my biggest reason for wanting to buy an unbranded phone is to avoid bloatware, but honestly, this phone isn't too bad in that respect. Not that i have noticed thus far anyway.

I was very happy at first with my purchase, as this is a very powerful phone.But, seems that there's a growing issue in which areas of the screen die and get unresponsive.In my case it was the Navigation Bar, but other people in forums have this same issue in different areas of the touchscreen too.

I got this phone from T Mobile two weeks ago.First, many personal settings within the Samsung apps and have been removed.  For example, I prefer my screen to be dark, they've removed this choice, all apps are annoyingly bright white and hurt my eyes.Second, I know the slender body is for easier hold, but they've scrunched the keyboard (I've actually had to come back and edit this review with a real keyboard for all of the grammatical and spelling errors this little tiny keyboard left me with here).  I'm not some old person lacking in dexterity.  It is difficult to swipe and I'm often hitting the wrong key or inadvertently switching screens.Third,  yeah, the camera is just ok.Fourth, I should've qualified for a TV through Samsung getting this phone.  I jumped through a myriad of hoops just for them to deny me on an unstated loophole.To say the least, I disliked the S8 and, I dislike the l this S9 even more.  I'll be trading it in asap.

The screen is amazing, it takes better pictures than most point and shoot cameras, has amazing battery life, and the performance of the Snapdragon 845 blows almost all the competitors out of the water. The iris/face scanning works very quickly and is effective even through sunglasses for me (as long as they're not mirrored/reflective), and if you do need the fingerprint sensor Samsung finally put it in a natural, convenient location where you finger just kind of lands on it when you pick up or are holding the phone. Also, coming from an iPhone I can say Samsung Pay is by far the best mobile payment solution out there thanks to MST (magnetic secure transmission) which lets it work almost anywhere as it simulates a traditional magnetic card swipe rather than requiring stores to upgrade to NFC payment terminals.There are entire articles that do detailed reviews of phones, so I'll cut that review here as I have no complaints about the phone... possibly other than the Bixby button, but that can be remapped or disabled.

Wound up settling for an S9 after my first couple choices turned out to not be fully compatible with Ting's network partners. Phone is decently fast (I'm coming from a E4Plus so my standards are probably low). The curved glass is a nuisance. It seems to be impossible to find a screen protector with good reviews. Not happy with the case choices either. Have an otterbox defender right now but it doesn't come with any kind of screen protection thanks to the...curved screen. The edge pull out menu is too fiddly to bother with.Bixby is a fracking nuisance. You have to agree to Bixby sending off your data in order to get to the control panel to sort of turn it off (you can't actually turn it off but you can make it require a double press of the Bixby button before you trigger Clippy 2.0).Android Pie update worked well enough. Took 4 or 5 restarts between the security and galaxy app updates before and after and the 9.0 update itself. I figured it made sense to get the update out of the way since I was coming from 7.0 that way I only have to relearn android once. Apparently you can't change the icon shapes on Samsung's implementation of Pie without installing a new launcher. The new icons look pretty doofy.The Samsung Smart Switch data transfer failed using the supplied dongle and cord from my E4 (the app errored out on the Samsung) but worked fine via WiFi.Fingerprint reader works well, facial recognition much less so.Camera doesn't seem amazing but I haven't really played with it much. There's a pretty intense yellow cast to indoor shots. I haven't done any outdoor shots yet. It's surprisingly easy to get a booger hook in the way taking a photo given how tall this phone is.In my perfect world the phone would be a bit wider and shorter so it'd fit in a pocket better. This phone sticks out just as much as my old phone. I usually carry the phone in my shirt pocket and do a lot of bending and lifting at work so my E4Plus has taken a lot of tumbles (shout out to Supershieldz and Urban Armor for it emerging unscathed). Given how hard it is to protect this thing and how how pricey it is I have some trepidation.

Quality hardware.  Software took a step back on T-Mobile network.  If you are a T-Mobile customer and travel internationally, think twice before buying the Galaxy S9 or S9+.  You will get a warning about data roaming every 10-15 minutes when you travel outside the U.S.  No way to turn off the warnings.  Only happens with Galaxy S8/S9, not earlier Galaxy models or other brands.  This problem was first reported 9 months ago but has not been fixed as of today (August 23, 2018).  Buyer beware!!!

Clearly I am not a Samsung fanboy. I purchased an S6 that I was unhappy with. The amount of "bloatware" and "pushed" software was incredible. The phone's performance was at best lackluster. I traded it in after a few months. Then the S9 came out with much fanfare and reviews that often put ahead of anything else. It's as bad or worse than the S6. Yes performance is way ahead, but the "bloatware" and "pushed" software is worse than ever.The touch screen seems ultra sensitive at the edge, but try touching in the middle. It's hit or miss, even with the sensitivity set to believe I have a screen protector which I don't. Opening the screen sometimes reveals the home page, sometimes it is some other random thing from an app. Then there's "butt dials" that I'm not sure are truly butt dials as I have had more in 3 months than I have had in in total over the last 3 years! While on that subject, I an be walking around with my phone in my pocket and it suddenly starts playing music. The local Verizon store has attempted to resolve many of these issues without success. They have offered to replace the phone, but the one that they sent me was "refurbished" and had many scratches on the screen-light but still scratches. I refused it. All this makes me wonder how the reviews could be so positive. Farewell Samsung.

I recently traded in my iPhone 7 Plus for my new S9 Plus. HUGE mistake. Bixby is the absolute worst voice assistance program I have every used. Understands me about 10% of the time. Works ok with Bixby button, but voice wake up (Hi Bixby) will not work. I've reset, uninstalled app, and uninstalled updates. No luck. Luckily, OK Google works perfectly. I definitely recommend disabling Samsung Voice service from your keyboard settings. Voice transcription is horrible. Google Voice Service seems to work almost flawlessly. Also, I do not care for the camera. Compared to my iPhone, the photos taken in "Live Zoom" mode are too oversaturated and blurry. Everything appears to have an orange glare.The keyboard is also terrible. Auto correct never works, auto-capitalization fails to capitalize my "I's." I love the screen, the themes, and Especially love Samsung Pay, but I miss my iPhone.

I received it on April 11 2018 and sadly it was used. As soon as I opened the box, phone was upside down, box was disorganized and headphones & cables misplaced.I needed the phone so much that i stayed with it but if you have another option simply go for another one.

Samsung makes amazing phones. No doubt. The build is awesome. The software is abysmal. There's so much bloatware and  all you can do is disable it not uninstall it.  This is a common issue but I shelled out 900 dollars for a phone and Samsung has the nerve to tell me what I'm allowed to uninstall from it?! Bixby is terrible. Awful. Trash. And yet I have a button for it that I can't remap. Guess what I can do?disable it. Yup. A dead button is better to Samsung than a button I can use on my almost $1k phone. The update speed is one of the worst of any brand of Android phone manufacturers. I switched carriers so I don't get OTA updates. I was told that Samsung switch would work. So no big deal right? It doesn't. It says my phones are up to date and it's 2 months behind in security patches. My S7 active was on nougat when oreo was out and it said I was up to date. Samsung's solution? Visit a Best buy store every month to get the update. GTFO.  The hardware is awesome. Wonderful camera. Amazing screen. Long lasting battery. But that software is trash. Complete trash.If you read all that and still want it kudos to youIf you have a pixel 2xl and want this I'll trade you lol.

First let me say that most of the negative reviews I have read about this phone are from people complaining about samsung bloatware, too many notifications, or bixby. The people who are complaining about this dont know how to use the phone. First of all you can disable a lot of bloatware apps and for the ones that you cannot disable, you are able to hide those apps. For notifications, you can disable notifications for any apps that you choose. As for bixby, you can disable the bixby button as well as turn off bixby home if you dont like it. I honestly forgot that bixby was on this phone.Now that I've gotten that out of the way, over all this phone is amazing and truly premium. Touchwiz is fluid and intuitive. The fingerprint sensor has been moved to an ideal location, the speakers sound really cool with Dolby atmos. It's TRUE surround sound especially when you watch a video in landscape mode, the sound is really cool. The intelligent scan has worked great for me but I dont use it that much. I've had this phone for about 2 months now and it's still extremely fast and snappy. The overall interface is beautiful.My only negatives about this phone are in regards to the camera because I wish it had a dual lens rear camera like the s9+. Not sure why samsung didnt make this phone with the dual lenses. The camera is still good, but this would have been cool to have. My other complaint is the camera interface is a little bit odd and takes some getting used to.Overall it's a truly premium phone. Best android experience you can get in my opinion. Samsung packs so many features into their phones and I love it. Some people complain about this but I love exploring these features.

I got this as a replacement for two S7 Edges that I had to return. I figured it'd make sense to try for a fancy new phone, seeing as it has been many moons since I've had an actual brand new phone. I was deciding between this and the OnePlus 5, but this came with a bunch of free stuff and I have had major issues with getting support for products that aren't sold or supported by my wireless carrier, plus the OnePlus had a couple of weird compatibility issues that I wasn't as much of fan of.Pros and cons here:+ Amazing camera-- performs great in low light, much faster than previous models, and some fun new features.+ Fast processor. Fast fingerprint sensor and many more options for unlocking that I haven't tried yet.+ Much faster startup than S7 Edge.+ Excellent battery life. I can go through the whole day without worrying about running out of power, which is great, because now I have to buy all new freaking USB-C chargers, because capitalism.- Bixby is truly horrendous-- would rather not have anything at all than a built-in personal assistant that is completely useless, doesn't understand basic speech, and can't really do anything. "Bixby, is there a hardware store around here?" "Let me see... do you want to call John Doe?" Made worse by the fact that Samsung has attempted to needlessly gamify the Bixby concept, so you get experience points when you talk to it.- Samsung tells me that the voice-to-text that they use in the Samsung keyboard is the same as the Bixby voice recognition, which is effectively useless. It misses every other word and mistranslates most words. I had very few issues with my S6, S7, or BlackBerry Q10 before that.- Fingerprint sensor is mildly frustrating on the back but you do get used to it.- Lack of a home key is sometimes unreliable for full-screen applications.- Some issues with unreliable full-screen/split-screen performance within specific software. I've had this issue only with YouTube and Google Maps, but it's frustrating.- Battery, while taking a long time to get to 5%, will die almost immediately as soon as it hits, say, 3 or 4%. I know this is a question of software rather than hardware as far as how they display it, but my S6 and S7 were much more accurate in terms of how much life was actually left. It is the difference between having to run to a charger to ensure that your phone doesn't turn off in the middle of doing something and, well, keeping it on.- Takes FOREVER to charge with the OEM charger-- a couple of hours to a full charge and no quick charging on the factory OEM charger. Sometimes won't charge at all with lower-ampacity chargers, which is an obnoxious design flaw of planned obsolescence slash idiocy.- Some software issues that I didn't have on the S7 and S6 including with Netflix, some radio streaming apps, Facebook, and odds and ends with a couple of other things. I'm used to these things taking several months to get resolved.- I've had some charging issues that no one, including Samsung, Amazon, or T-Mobile, will propose resolving other than to replace my device. This is the third replacement phone I've tried to get for my S6 Edge, whose battery life started to wane to the point of being totally unusable after a couple of years. It's extremely frustrating to deal with this.I will revise my review in another couple of months-- will see how it goes.

Good features but serious flaws for expensive price.  The GPS never works right.  Using other phones with gps apps work excellent. The Samsung device is useless.  Second phone model where the ridiculous location for a fingerprint reader is in the rear.  Half the time most users will need to pick up the phone to scan a finger.  Often, the camera lenses gets dirty being near the fingerprint reader.  Just plain lack of common sense. Lastly, it lags in performance. My Sony phone of half the price is always much faster than the Samsung.  Samsung is the new Apple is ridiculous pricing for the value.

This is a fantastic phone.  Awesome screen, and the camera is good enough that you don't need to purchase a separate camera to take pictures.  well thought out and very fast.  We purchased the 256GB version directly from samsung.  It also has a microSD card slot, so you can add another 400GB on top of the 256GB internal.The wireless charging is also great.  it works even when there is a leather case on the phone.  not sure how it works, but it's pretty cool.

I didn't see the point in spending this much money on a phone, when something a third of the price will make calls, have internet access etc. However, my good camera packed up at this time. After reading how good the camera is on the S9, I hoped to save replacing my good camera, and travel only with the S9.However, the reality is that the photos are still from a limited size camera with a very small lens. I consider the photos to be very good from something this small, however, they can't replace a reasonably good dedicated camera. It can take great shots in the right conditions, and I'm very impressed with the panoramic shots.The "ok Google" feature is good. Face recognition works well. I haven't figured out what Bixby is supposed to do. I have wireless charging, which us useful, and will hopefully mean there is no plug damage, and I should get a couple of decades life out of the phone. It's still a nuisance having to charge the phone every couple of days.Note, this is from someone who has never taken a selfie (and probably never will). I use it for internet and data so rarely that I have these normally turned off to preserve battery life.  If I had my choice again, I'd have bought something much cheaper, along with a good travel camera.

So my review of this phone may be a bit different than others I have never heard of anyone else having the complaints I have with the most recent of the Samsung line up. With that said I will start with what I do like the S9 has the best camera I have ever used that is the single thing keeping me on Samsung currently. I also love everything software wise besides Bixby I always hit it by accident coming from the Lg G6 I am used to volume down being there. But here's my issue with it the screen curve away from the viewer annoys the crap out of me if i prop my phone up with its stand to watch videos the curved part usually gets a glare and it makes the phone far less easy to protect with the screen being way more open to contact on dropping it. I have decided when LG makes a new phone like the G7 maybe I will go back because I really enjoyed the flatter screens and the Lg setup was more appealing (No Bixby) but I will miss this amazing camera if LG slips up in that department.

Had several generations of S phones.  This 1 seems to be going backwards instead of forwards as far as inovations and features. 2 gens ago did voice recognition texting.  Where did that go.  Screen scratches more easily.  OS updates weekly that are buggy.  Search engine querry randomly locks up phone.  Too many keystrokes to do what i want.  Not intuitive.

The product came as brand new and arrived just in time for christmas! I've had it for a few weeks now, and it is definitely a stellar phone. I upgraded from the Samsung S4, and I also used an iPhone for a bit and can say I love this phone. Plus the curved edges make wallpapers and photos look nice. For some reason I was having trouble with the Sim ejector tool that came with it but when I went to my local carrier they were able to pop in a sim just fine. I also couldn't disable Bixby for the longest time until literally a few minutes ago, for some reason I never got the cog wheel at the top and the settings for Bixby voice until like I said, a few minutes ago. Honestly just glad that I am finally able to disable it completely, wished I didn't have to wait so soon. Hope to keep this phone in good condition so I can resell it down the road. Plus, I got a one year warranty as prescribed.Note: I bought from Amazon and NOT a third party seller. If you do then it's on you. Also many people leaving reviews didn't even buy from Amazon itself, and it's confusing people as to why there are so many low ratings. My advice is to buy from Amazon and you should be fine.

I made similar comments about the S8. This phone is a great upgrade from that. Two things stand out for me. One is the improved picture quality at night and the second is the size. I have big hands and I work on screens a lot so my eyes are easily tired. Having a bigger screen helps.This phone feels strong and robust in the hand. It has heft that speaks of its quality. The screen is amazing and I get great battery life that is easily two days if I use it sparingly. Used heavily it easily makes it to the end of a long day.What would I improve? For one a slightly bigger screen. Also make them more affordable. Having to fork out so much money for a phone seems ridiculous. OK its the best phone in the world but still. This costs more than many 60" LCD TVs. How is that even possible?

The main issues with the S9 Plus are with camera performance. The rear and front cameras consistently overexpose the shots. This was a problem on the S8 as well. In addition, selfie shots are a bit soft and a little washed out. If you're not picky about photos from a high priced phone, then go for it.Other gripes are the half dozen Samsung apps that cannot be uninstalled and the Bixby button that can't be remapped (typical Samsung)

Have owned a galaxy s series since the original galaxy s but I think the 9+ will be my last Samsung phone. The android platform was meant to be open and unrestricted so quit forcing me to have apps that I dont want but cant remove. Your Bixby spyware is an unwanted waste of space and resources that cant be disabled,  uninstalled, or removed in any way, and quit limiting the bluetooth max volume further with each update. I am a truck driver and use my phone for work purposes and bluetooth the phone to my truck for GPS and music while driving15 on the volume used to blow me out of the truck, now (3 updates later) 25 on the volume and I can barely hear the music and GPS instructions above the road noise and forget answering a call via a separate bluetoothed headset while going down the road, cant hear it at all over the road noise due to the additional volume limitations that have been added with each update. Another thing, quit with the volume warning every damn time I turn the volume over half, most bluetooth devices have separate volume controls independent of the phone, so ofcourse I turn the phone up all the way then adjust with the volume controls on the bluetooth device, I dont need to be nannied by my phone. As I said earlier, i think this will be my last Samsung phone. If I wanted a proprietary nanny phone I would have bought an iphone...

The amount of bloatware this phone comes with is unprecedented. Samsung needs to stop with the outdated, unnecessary programs or LET OWNERS DELETE THEM. I feel like I bought a car and the trunk came stuffed with crap I don't want or need, and I can't remove it to put things I want in there. Shame on Samsung. What other industry gets away with this? I don't want to have to hack my own phone to get rid of crap I never asked for!

This phone is alright, but it is nothing compared to the Finney by SirinLabs.com. The Finney is ultra SECURE, with a built in cold storage wallet for crypto lovers. It has 128 GB of internal storage upgradeable to two terrabytes. The Finney has decent cameras, a great battery, 6GB of ram, and the phone can pay you over $300 back through short videos when you get the phone. More videos will be added in the future, making the phone not a purchase, but a mo ey maker. The Finney runs on the blockchain technology with SECURE calling, messages, internet trafic, and IPS, as well as other security measures. The Finney is also a breeze to use.

The phone is good but not a great. First the curved screen is annoying if you use the phone without a case because touching these edges by mistake will block the other parts inputs plus the edges are more light reflective than the middle part so watching a movie on the gym or bright place is annoying. The second problem is that, we are in 2018 and I still don't get it why Samsung still hasn't added the " Screen turns on by notification" feature yet when 99% of the phones today have this feature. Lastly, the power save on the phone is still bad, If someone is new to Samsung will not know he or she needs to turn off the battery saving mode on some apps such as Gmail and Yahoo mail, or their E-mails will be arrived late.

How on earth can half of people who have bought this phone here have issues  from phone not powering or losing power quickly to receiving empty boxes? Those giving it five stars one wonders whether its by mare luck they got good phones or they are just part of scheme to fool people to buy useless phones. Now it seems all the phones being sold as being refurbished  had a problem which could not be easily fixed , so the phones are just fixed to be functioning for a short period before they break down.

It's a good phone overall.... And I love everything about it.... My only issue is that after 2 months, there was a ton of lagging. I've never experienced this much lagging in any of my old Samsung's phones (S3, S6, S7, S8)  but got damn this one does it a lot. I clear my ram often and restart my phone almost every 3 days. IDK if anyone else is experiencing this but I know Samsung has a reputation of phone lagging. Again great phone and there's my only issue.

I got this phone when it first went on sale. I was surprised at how small the bezels were on the phone and how great the picture was. This phone has a very large pixel per square inch. The speakers are amazing on this phone, one of the best in the market. There is a speaker on the bottom like usual but the speaker where you put your ear up to talk on the phone doubles as a media speaker for everything that is on your phone, not just calls. The battery at first use to last about a day and a half but not it only last about 3/4 of a day. I usually have to charge it after dinner. Overall this phone is very similar to the Galaxy s8 but has a couple improvements that makes it better.

I am using this phone for more than 3 months now and I feel that it is superior in every way compared to new iPhone XS.The screen is AMAZING. I mean, it is really great and doesn't have that ugly bezel from iPhoneCamera quality is just about the same. You cannot really tell a difference.The battery life is almost the same and the processor speed is just unbelievable!If you're buying it at the current price point, you are actually getting the same/better phone for about 300 dollars cheaper! Well, it's always been the case though, so nothing surprising.

To access the home screen or menu of your favorites, you have to swipe the edge of the screen. Unfortunately, If you already have an app on the screen this swiping will frequently affect the app instead of showing the menu.This is very frustrating and is wasting my time.I advise you to pick a better phone.

this is a great phone with excellent battery lifegreat for people who are power usersvery fast i upgraded from a galaxy s7 edge to the galaxy s9 plus coral bluethe s9 plus has edge screen and if you turn your phone over during a sound or notification it will stop the sound.the speakers are very  loud once you turn on dolby atmosthe cameras are wonderful.this is a must buy.

I recently purchased a s9 plus from verizon. So far it seems to work better than my s5,but the glass screen seems to scratch very easily.  I have been very careful but scratches keep appearing , almost over night. I'm beginning to wonder. I'm not happy about the durability of the glass screen.

Originally all was great one of the two phones purchased the microphone has stopped working.  Went through all the online recommendations to correct this.  It only works with the headset plugged into it.

VERY FAST GREAT SOUND GREAT PICTURE QUALITY, bought mine at bestbuy.com refurbished unlocked, saved over$200 off new price, no issues (7 days in so far) based on the reviews here I would suggest making sure the shipper is a reputable vendor or just go to store as this is a high dollar item and its a lot easier to deal with live people.

Good - It's a good phone, no doubt about it.  Feels sturdy, something about slow motion, NFC, all the fancy features (you can read the other reviews and marketing jazz).Bad - Now here is what gets me - this fancy screen is fragile.  Be aware - the SCREEN IS NOT COVERED BY WARRANTY.  Even with all kinds of screen protectors, drop this phone and you risk the screen cracking.Yes, friends it happens much easier than it should.  We had the same issue with the S8 and the S9.  It was dropped from a reasonable height (between knee and hip - the exact height you will carry and use it at) and both the S8 and S9 shattered.The worst part is that Samsung refuses to cover the screen under their "warranty."The local shop they sent us to did fix the 9 for about $100 less than the S8 (total was $235 for the S9 fix).  Also, remember this phone just came out, we've had it less than two months.  The shop said they already had 20+ people in with broken S9 screens.Wish i could go back to non-curved, more durable devices.

I've been a fan of the Galaxy series, both tablets and phones, having extensive experience with the S5, S6, S8 and now the S9+. The S9+ has dual rear-facing cameras, a first in the series. This feature alone was worth upgrading as I'm an avid amateur photographer with several nice DSLR cameras, but face it, I take far more photos with my phone simply because it's always with me.Transitioning from the S8 to S9+ took an hour but was smooth as silk.  *Everything* transferred automatically - apps, pics, files, settings - including the kitchen sink. LolI highly recommend - 5 golden stars!

I absolutely love this new phone. I upgraded from a note 4 to this product.  There is a small learning curve  as my previous phone was so old however the price is $50 cheaper for an unlocked phone then it is to purchase from Verizon locked.  I especially appreciate the adapter that is included so you can connect your old phone to the new phone and transfer all of your data.

Looks brand  new,  great pictures, fun to  use .this  is a huge  upgrade  for me, and I am enjoying it so much was surprised  that  the  charger has changed since my  S5. Still  learning  about  phone  but loving  it

I returned it because it is so much more than the ZTE and only offers modest upgrades in comparison. That being said, the phone itself is beautiful and well made with lots of great features, but the price point is the killer based on its mild competition. This is my third Samsung Galaxy after switching from the original iPhone.  This was a huge upgrade from my Galaxy Alpha.  The operating system is way way more polished and the camera is superior to my Panasonic Lumix.  My wife's Galaxy S8 seems just about the same but the 9 is noticeably zippier but I have way fewer apps.  In our household we have Macs, PC's, iPads, Roku's, Tablets so we aren't married to any particular brand.  For the phones I've enjoyed Samsungs.  My wife got a deal on an LG and it was a big headache as it had hardware failures.Important, currently, as of this writing the S9 has a software problem where notifications on the apps DOES NOT work.  Since I've come to rely on those little numbers on the top left corner of my apps this is an inconvenience.  My old Samsung came with SVoice which I prefer over Bixby for simplicity but it's slowly winning me over.  Ask Bixby to Rap for you, it's hilarious.

I had the S8 and screens were slipping and sliding/opening and closing.  That was resolved either with an update or one of many calls to Verizon (don't recall.) Also lost audio at 2 1/2 years of owning.  My boyfriend shot some compressed air into the audio part and I could hear much better. But I had already ordered the S9 since I didn't think we could fix the audio on the S8.  I'm having so many issues with it.  I was on the phone with Verizon for 6 hours yesterday - different techs. After exhaustive trouble shooting, it was determined that I got a defective phone!  What are the odds?  When I try to google, email or text, I get knocked out into home screen.  Very frustrating to try 8x to complete a 6 line text.  Perhaps it's that the screen is too sensitive. It's not the apps - we put it in Safe Mode.  We changed everything around including Samsung keyboard to Gboard, thinking that was the problem - wasn't. I'm glad that nobody else got a defective phone who has given a review.  Aren't I the lucky one?  I think I'm still lucky in other ways - it's hit and miss whether you get a functioning phone.  New phone arriving tomorrow and will go to Verizon store for set up as I did with this phone.  Wish me luck please!  Thanks.

Battery life beats the pants off the Marshmallow S5's best day, I'm sure Oreo (and now Pie) have something to do with that. Even though it isn't the Qualcomm chipset, being USA and all, it still is more than fast enough. Got an unlimited Data Plan with the Sparq company, and zero problem with 4GLte watching March Madness. No lagging on any app, or while switching apps, that I've noticed. No feeling of remorse that I didn't wait and get an S10.Fits my hand, fits my needs, and the price was very nice. I've used Amazon Warehouse before, and was disappointed only once - and they took it right back. No problem this time at all. Used - Like New? For the Win!!

I used to be a huge fan of Samsung Galaxy phones and have purchased an S4, two S5s, S8 and now S9. Unfortunately, I see Samsung's S9 as one of the most annoying products I have ever owned. The S9 has very poor battery life and never makes it through a day. The camera is disappointing and, of course, the phone comes packed with Samsung's useless bloatware. The worst part of the S9 experience for me is that Samsung forces system updates on users, which cannot be delayed or declined. Each update changes both the look and feel of the phone, and things you have previously configured to your liking. Each update also removes valuable features. The latest 2019 update did the following things: (1) removed the 'disable icon frames' option from Settings meaning every icon now has an ugle white background; (2) disables all Bixby button remapping apps -- Bixby is a very poor voice-based assistant designed to harvest your information and Samsung does not allow users to disable it so it interrupts phone use whenever the side button is accidentally pressed; (3) the Jan 2019 update has also disables Navbar Apps, which performs a function the S9 cannot perform, makign the color of the Navbar at the bottom of the screen match the color of the onscreen app so you now have a hideous white stripe at the bottom of any dark-themed app, (4) the Jan 2019 update has replaced the icon set with an ugly set of cartoonish icons suited to a 6-year old's toy. I could list many more annoyances with the S9 experience, but let me cut to the bottom line: Samsung has no interest in giving customers the product/features they want. Samsung wants to control every aspect of how you use and set up your Android device to make you use their proprietary apps and AI. Instead of providing the features that users want, Samsung disables great apps that provide those very features. Instead of allowing user choice over things like Bixby, Samsung coerces their customers by making it impossible to disable them. Samsung's entire product philosophy is arrogant, high-handed and tone deaf. If it were not for a faster processor and 4G capability, I would rate the S9 as an inferior product to the S5 from some years ago. The S5 had user-replaceable battery (no built-in obsolescence to create new landfills), no stupid curved screen edges, no extremely annoying Bixby, and more user configurability over the features and experience smartphone users want. Samsung is going in exactly the wrong direction and I bitterly regret spending several hundred on an S9. I will never buy another Samsung product.
